LEAKS.Definition: secret information that was made known

TRIALS.Definition: hearings or examinations of the case in a court of law

ALLEGED.Definition: said, without proof, to have committed crimes

MASTERMIND.Definition: the person who had planned and organised it

ALLIES.Definition: people who helped and supported him

TRIAL.Definition: hearing or examination of the case in a court of law

ALLEGATIONS.Definition: statements and claims, made without proof, that they were guilty

SHED.Definition: a small building used for storing things

ACCOMPLICES.Definition: people who helped him commit the crime

REMAINDER.Definition: the amount that was left to be paid

INTERMEDIARIES.Definition: people who had acted as a link or connection between them

DAMNING.Definition: suggesting very strongly that he was guilty

OFFSHORE.Definition: based abroad to avoid taxation or control

BRIBE.Definition: amount of money paid in exchange for some favour or help

FIXER.Definition: the person who had arranged it

TESTIMONY.Definition: statement or claim about what had happened

OSTENSIBLY.Definition: apparently, as it appears to be

COVERUP.Definition: attempt or try to keep it secret or hidden

PARANOID.Definition: worried because he believed that they would try to harm him

TURN OUT.Definition: prove to be the case, happen

BIZARRELY.Definition: in a strange and unusual way

VEHEMENTLY.Definition: in a strong and passionate way

FINGERS BEING POINTED.Definition: people being blamed or considered responsible for the crimes

MAINTAINING THAT.Definition: continuing to claim or say that

EXECUTORS.Definition: the people who put it into effect or performed it

KIDNAPPER.Definition: a person who abducted or took away someone and held them captive, typically in order to demand money in exchange for their release

STABBED.Definition: hit, struck with a sharp object

GET RID OF.Definition: be free of, do away with

TURNOUT.Definition: the percentage of the population that actually voted

CONVICTION.Definition: the fact of officially finding them guilty

JUDICIARY.Definition: the authorities that are responsible for the country's legal system

OMINOUS.Definition: worrying, giving the impression that something bad is going to happen
